doc.field: The Angkor Wat is at the top of the high classical style of Khmer architecture. It has become a symbol of Cambodia,and appears on its national flag, and it is the country's prime attraction for visitors. Now if this isn't a beautiful sight, what is? This is a closer pre-sunrise shot of the central towers of the temple. Eagerly awaiting the rising sun now. It was a surreal sight. And for once, I was quite unmindful of the fidgety army of tourists and photographers all around me. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

Time to leave the Angkor Wat, but before I do, I simply must have myself photographed against the moat. It was pretty hot outside with the sun up high, and in my hurry, I made my usual error of not switching off the flash. With such bright back-lighting, the filler flash is crucial, but this is something I'm still learning by bitter experience. Note to self: wake up dammit! (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

Approaching the main Angkor Wat temple, here is a scene from the huge entrance corridor. Note debris from the ruined temples strewn in the foreground. Several countries like Japan, Korea, India, France and others are helping restoration of the scores of temples in the Angkor archaeological park. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple angkorwatentrancecorridor

Forward two steps, as I know the curiosity is killing you: this is a far shot of Angkor Wat as seen from the reflecting pool between the entrance complex and the main temple. The Angkor Wat is the largest Hindu (later Buddhist) temple complex in the world, situated at Angkor, in Siem Reap, Cambodia, built by King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century as his state temple and capital city. As the best-preserved temple at the site, it is the only one to have remained a significant religious centre since its foundation â€“ first Hindu, dedicated to the god Vishnu, then Buddhist (after subsequent invasions). And yes, that's me in the foreground. Called the 'reflecting pool', the stagnant body of water in the foreground looks rather unimpressive by day, but gives an ethereal look and feel when you catch the sunrise at Angkor Wat. (pictures later in this set.) (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

Another of the impressive shriness of the Angkor Wat entrance corridor. This is actually a multi pillared hall running all around the temple. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008).

cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple angkorwatentrancecorridor

This is the Angkor Wat entrance plaza, or ticket offices. You must possess an admission pass (an 'Angkor Pass') to visit the temples and sites in the Angkor Archaeological Park. Entry is not cheap, you have to buy passes for one day (not much use, you cannot see anything in one day, there are so many temples and so spread out), three days or one week. You have to call here on the first day, to pick up your ticket. On subsequent days, your tuk tuk will compulsorily enter the plaza, but will drive around the building. A group of people are stationed at the exit who will check your ticket. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple ticketoffice angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkorpass angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple angkortemplesentranceplaza angkortemplesticketingoffices

Back on the entrance causeway, preparing for the nearly 1km trek in the hot afternoon sun to my tuktuk, I spot this scene, which turned out to be one of the more memorable scenes at the Angkor Wat temple. Here is a tourist delicately balancing her pink Canon camera on the stone causeway in an attempt to get a really low angle view of the Angkor Wat temple, the three spires of which are visible at the far end. The small compact camera was looking almost microscopic when viewed against those mighty structures. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

cambodia buddhism angkorwat tourist worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom touristphotographers theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple

You are not allowed to take the direct path from the entrance corridor. That's that multi pillared structure you see stretching into the distance. You need to get down a few steps, get onto the grass and follow the 'Visit this Way' signs. It's frustating, especially when it is hot, muggy and sweaty, when you have to take a roundabout route or a detour, but what can one do? Although most of Cambodia, especially the heavily touristed areas, and more especially the Angkor Wat, is totally landmine free, the thought of unexploded landmines keeps you on your fixed track. (I know, I know, it's just my imagination!) (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

A final shot of Angkor Wat, the surrounding moat and greenery around it from the highest point. After hovering for a few minutes at the highest point till which the balloon will go, we are now preparing to descend, to return to terra firma. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

As the sun rises higher, the crowd begins to thin. This is another silhouette shot of the Angkor Wat with the sun behind the temple. This is the reason one should avoid visiting the temple in the morning. As one of the few West facing Hindu temples, the light is always behind the structures in the mornings. The photographers with the heavy gear are all behind me now, (literally). Here a group of backpackers is getting pictures of each other with their simply point and shoot cameras and mobile phones. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat tourists worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple backpackers angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom touristphotographers theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples

A large group of Japanese tourists had descended upon the reflecting lotus pool to catch the Angkor Wat sunrise. There were using anything from advanced dSLR cameras to mobile phones to capture the scene. The paraplegic lady in the wheel chair really caught my attention. She was using her mobile phone and was quite ecstatic when she got the scene. She kept smiling and laughing to herself looking at the scene on her phone's display. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat tourists worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom touristphotographers theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples

The northern reflecting pool in front is the most popular sunrise location. To catch the sunrise, one needs arrive very early, well before sunrise. One can then see the sun rise behind the Angkor Wat, and providing a silhouette of Angkorâ€™s distinctively shaped towers against a pink colored sunrise sky. Some of the best colors appear just before the sun breaks over the horizon. Timing apart, another important reason for an early arrival is the hordes of photographers out in force, some with tripod and very advanced equipment. It's difficult to get a good vantage point with all those crowds and heavy photo gear, many tripod mounted, all over the place. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

sunrise cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap reflectingpool buddhisttemple angkorwatsunrise angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith sunriseoverangkorwat angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple sunriseoverthetemples

A dried out tank in the Angkor Wat main shrine. It is customary for most South Indian shrines to have a tank on the premises, where the devouts must bathe, or (nowadays at least dip their feet) before they enter the temple. This is supposed to cleanse the body (or nowadays feet) before entering a place of prayer. This tank would have most probably served the same purpose. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple templetank angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple

A massive Buddha statue inside the Angkor Wat temple. This is the only surviving statue from the original Khmer era. Most of the original statues were vandalized by invading troops, notably Vietnamese and Thai. In later years, many of the valuable statues were plundered by locals for the antiques market, becoming obscenely rich in the process, and ruining their own heritage in the process. (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)

cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple standingbuddha buddhastatue angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple

The sun is now well and truly up. I returned later in the day to head towards the temple. It is not a good idea to visit the temple early in the morning as the sun is directly behind the building (the Angkor Wat is one of the few West facing Hindu temples) but a late morning or early afternoon visit should be OK. This is a daytime shot of the Angkor Wat reflected in the lotus reflecting pool. It looks so ordinary now! It was magic several hours earlier at sunrise! (Siem Reap, Cambodia, Oct. 2008)
cambodia buddhism angkorwat worldheritagesite siemreap buddhisttemple angkorarchaeologicalpark khmerkingdom theruinsofangkor buddhistfaith angkortempleruins worldslargesthindutemple

Guests may visit the Cologne Cathedral daily at no cost. However, there is a charge to go up into the south tower which has a viewing platform at a height of 97 meters (318ft). Make sure you're ready for a climb of 509 steps as there is no elevator in the tower. including the 24 tons heavy Petersglocke (St. Peter's Bell), cast in 1923.

Nikon and Fuji are the last things you expect to see when you visit KÃ¶ln (Cologne) for its historic cathedral. Yet, these camera stores are the first things that greet you as you walk towards the cathedral entrance, as these shops are set against one of the cathedral walls. You can see the KÃ¶ln (Cologne) cathedral itself towering behind the commercial establishments. The KÃ¶ln cathedral is almost adjoining the Hauptbahnhof, it's just a few minutes walk. It was freezing cold and was beginning to rain. (Jan. 2008)

Cologne's magnificent Cathedral is the most renowned landmark in the city and serves as the seat of the Archbishop of Cologne. It is one of the largest churches in the world and for some time the cathedral even held the title of the world's tallest building. (Jan. 2008)

At the east end of the KÃ¶ln cathedral stands its greatest treasure, the Shrine of the Kings. It's a wooden casket containing the relics of the Magi,and is encased in a golden case, studded with jewels. Work on the Shrine of Kings casket was started in 1180, ad it took almost fifty years to complete. (Jan. 2008)
Cathedral interior, looking towards the east end. (Jan. 2008)

Also noteworthy at the KÃ¶ln cathedral are the large stained glass windows, which cover an area of about 10,000 sq meters (110,000 sq feet) and allow plenty of natural light to enter the building. The oldest window in the cathedral - known as the Ã„lteres Bibelfenster (Old Bible Window) - is in the chapel of the Three Magi. (Jan. 2008)

A view of the cathedral interior from where I was sitting. This is I think a view of the south nave. Too bad about the limitation of the cigarette pack sized Fuji Z2 camera. It wasn't suited to low light photography. (Jan. 2008)
Signage in the KÃ¶ln cathedral crypt shows the various cardinals bishops and their tenure. The KÃ¶ln cathedral is the seat of the Bishop of KÃ¶ln. (Jan. 2008)

One of the monks at the KÃ¶ln cathedral: his job seemed to be to keep people off the area behind the fence. The kindly soul did permit me to take his picture though. Too bad the file got corrupted (hence the grey band on the left). Oh well, what can one do when technology lets us down? (Jan. 2008)
Another view of the signage in the KÃ¶ln cathedral crypt which shows the various cardinals bishops and their tenure. The KÃ¶ln cathedral is the seat of the Bishop of KÃ¶ln. (Jan. 2008)

A nativity scene diorama was still in place near the KÃ¶ln cathedral entrance exit. Of course it was barely three weeks past Christmas. A huge crowd had gathered at the spot, hence a hurried grab shot. (Jan. 2008)

That's a self timer shot of moi inside the KÃ¶ln cathedral. Totally pooped, and with shaky, wobbly legs after the steep 509 step climb up, in freaking cold weather, I simply had to rest. It's a large cathedral, and there is plenty of seating for the devout. Now I'm not a Christian, in fact I'm not even a believer in God, but sitting in that cathedral for about half an hour with eyes closed and shut off to the world did overwhelm me with a sense of peace and calm. (Jan. 2008)
As I emerge from the crupt, I pass another shrine in the KÃ¶ln cathedral with a lot of candle burning going on. (Jan. 2008)
Another of the impressive stained glass windows of the KÃ¶ln cathedral, very painstakingly restored. (Jan. 2008)
Another view of the signage showing the various cardinals bishops at the KÃ¶ln cathedral and the tenure of their service. (Jan. 2008)
